text:
Passage planning with marks/buoys (system-agnostic).

Context:
You are approaching a narrow channel / marina entrance. You see lateral marks indicating the channel edges (left/right in your local system) and you suspect a shallow area near your intended track. You have a chartplotter and depth sounder available, but your crew is inexperienced.

Task:
Describe a safe passage plan:
1) What you do before entering (checks, briefings, settings, speed plan).
2) How you verify you are in the safe water (what instruments/cues, how you cross-check).
3) What you do if the depth decreases unexpectedly.
4) Name 3 typical beginner mistakes in this situation and how to prevent them.

Important: Avoid relying on mark colors; focus on the reasoning and cross-checks.
correct_answer:
Before entering: slow to a safe speed early; assign roles (helm, lookout, depth monitor); brief the crew on the plan and abort criteria; set chart scale appropriately; confirm datum/units; prepare fenders/lines if relevant; verify engine response and steering; consider wind/current set.

Verification: do not trust a single source. Use chartplotter track + depth trend + visual alignment with marks/leading lines where available. Cross-check GPS position with expected depths and mark spacing. Maintain a conservative offset from hazards and avoid cutting corners.

If depth decreases: immediately reduce speed, stop/neutral if needed, and back out along the known-safe track if possible. Avoid sharp turns at speed. Re-check chart scale, position, tide assumptions, and sensor health. If unsure, abort entry and reassess.

Typical mistakes: (1) entering too fast, (2) focusing on one instrument and losing visual lookout, (3) cutting between marks without understanding safe-water logic or assuming color conventions, (4) no crew roles/briefing. Prevention: slow earlier, assign tasks, use cross-checks, and keep an explicit abort plan.

ai_context: Score on: (1) pre-entry setup and crew briefing, (2) cross-check strategy (chart + depth + visuals), (3) safe-speed discipline, (4) concrete actions on unexpected shoaling, (5) explicit beginner mistakes and mitigations, (6) avoidance of color-dependent assumptions.
